Articles.Content:
The latest from 'Scarburough Avionics and Weapon Systems' - Scarburough UAV-1b Ghost! 

A highly capable unmanned stealth ordinance delivery system. It is also capable of many other tasks, such as reconnaissance and experimental testing. This variant comes equipped with a radar jammer to fully conceal any radar signature it may show, 6 hellfire missiles and a FLIR ball. 

Spoiler

![XtXnI6u.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/XtXnI6u.jpg)

Spoiler

![FIT1EiD.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/FIT1EiD.jpg)

Spoiler

![1dQ74lP.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/1dQ74lP.jpg)

Spoiler

![zE0AUVZ.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/zE0AUVZ.jpg)

**Edited <time datetime="2016-09-12T22:34:12Z" title="09/12/2016 10:34  PM" data-short="7 yr">September 12, 2016</time> by Deizelpunk**
  
Wanted to add pics.

Pretty old, but this give you some ideas? the bay doors open downwards. Uses yaw brakes for steering, the little fins are just for a bit of directional stability & help reduce yawing in turns.

[![21522173779_0512e73e3a_b.jpg](https://c4.staticflickr.com/1/767/21522173779_0512e73e3a_b.jpg)](https://flic.kr/p/yMQLrH)

[![21090077103_0d1a3392d0_b.jpg](https://c8.staticflickr.com/1/612/21090077103_0d1a3392d0_b.jpg)](https://flic.kr/p/y8Eaa2)

Building something like an actual B-2 also works:

[![21721820671_6d16f1c51b_b.jpg](https://c8.staticflickr.com/6/5726/21721820671_6d16f1c51b_b.jpg)](https://flic.kr/p/z6u1vv)

just not the best thing you could build.

Im still not 100% sure how to make them stable, the lack of inspiration isn't the problem. If you look at my last comment I made a lil flying wing drone, but when I scale that design (the wing twist included) its just so unstable. An explanation on how to make them work better would be helpful. Cool planes tho.
Actually I found this really useful page here: [http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1297516](http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1297516)
You haven't explained \*how\* your craft are unstable, so we can't really help directly.

> 
> 
> 21 minutes ago, Van Disaster said:
> 
> 
> You haven't explained \*how\* your craft are unstable, so we can't really help directly.
> 

Well the same problem everyone has with flying wings, no yaw stability. Im just trying to figure out how the real life ones work. So far from what i can tell its a combo of differential thrust, wing sweep and wing twist. Not exactly sure still tho.

> 
> 
> 1 hour ago, Deizelpunk said:
> 
> 
> Well the same problem everyone has with flying wings, no yaw stability. Im just trying to figure out how the real life ones work. So far from what i can tell its a combo of differential thrust, wing sweep and wing twist. Not exactly sure still tho.
> 

Some tailless planes use split airbrakes on each wingtip for yaw control, see [this image](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/US_Air_Force_B-2_Spirit.jpg).  You need a pretty good flight control system to deal with that though, and I'm not sure <abbr title="Stability Augmentation System">SAS</abbr> or any other system in KSP is up to the task.

> 
> 
> Just now, blowfish said:
> 
> 
> Some tailless planes use split airbrakes on each wingtip for yaw control, see [this image](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dc/US_Air_Force_B-2_Spirit.jpg).  You need a pretty good flight control system to deal with that though, and I'm not sure <abbr title="Stability Augmentation System">SAS</abbr> or any other system in KSP is up to the task.
> 

Yeah, <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> yaw doesn't really cut it either. ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif ":(")

<abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> yaw brakes work fine, they just take a lot of setting up. You can see the near brakes active on that b-2ish thing. Might want to use Pilot Assistant instead of stock <abbr title="Stability Augmentation System">SAS</abbr> though.

The only way I could have made this more unstable was give it anhedral; it's under full autopilot in this shot, it's only problem was lack of drag! extremely hard to land.

[![22174297369_bd87678efc_b.jpg](https://c2.staticflickr.com/1/584/22174297369_bd87678efc_b.jpg)](https://flic.kr/p/zMt54T)

What I've never got to work satisfactorily in <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> is mixing inputs other than adding <abbr title="Angle of Attack">AoA</abbr> to primary controls.

Earlier I expressed concern that the <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> Zq derivative is displayed with the opposite sign of my expectation.

Spoiler

> 
> 
> On 2/22/2016 at 3:25 AM, Rodhern said:
> 
> 
> As you can probably tell I am still new to <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr>.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> I have this simple craft. It is a command pod, three girder boxes and four wing parts.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> [![Zq-craft.jpg](http://www.act-consult.net/Rodhern/Games/KSP/Temp1/Zq-craft.jpg)](http://www.act-consult.net/Rodhern/Games/KSP/Temp1/Zq-craft.jpg "Enlarge image")
> 
> 
> 
> 
> From looking at the picture I would guess that a positive pitch up rotation will induce a upward acceleration (negative Z-direction acceleration) as the wing surfaces are forced downwards.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On the <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> stability derivatives tab however the Zq derivative is positive. Can someone explain that to me?
>

Now I have a new craft that also seems to display an opposite Zq derivative.

Do you have any good ideas how I can test/debug a craft to check if the pitch-up induced acceleration points upwards or downwards?

I hope I'm not too late for the flying-wing-party... date-volume limit prevented downloading stuff (playing on another PC now) before Deizel made his bomber himself, so I decided to build a cargo plane based on Mk 3 fuselages (as he said that increasing size was the problem).

Spoiler

![Kx2r4BT.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/Kx2r4BT.jpg)

Testing isn't done yet, and there'll probably be some adjustments. Relies on <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> stability assists for stability (yes, pitch too. And any landing attempts without roll assist failed as well).

**Edited <time datetime="2016-09-15T18:04:36Z" title="09/15/2016 06:04  PM" data-short="7 yr">September 15, 2016</time> by FourGreenFields**

What about plane full of fuel that can takeoff at 0.3 mach (90 m/s) and fly at speeds up to 6 mach before engine meltdown?

This plane uses Tweak Scale, <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> and AJE.

Also I have Kerbalism on realism mode and 40 other mods.

RAPIERS doesn't have generators apparently [@blowfish](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/119688-blowfish/)

[http://imgur.com/a/5qLML](http://imgur.com/a/5qLML)

Hi [@ferram4](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/21328-ferram4/)

I asked this question a while ago. The main thread is these three questions.

[Picture of craft](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/109098-official-far-craft-repository/&do=findComment&comment=2423568)  
[Z-direction answer](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/109098-official-far-craft-repository/&do=findComment&comment=2423680)  
[continued confusion](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/109098-official-far-craft-repository/&do=findComment&comment=2423700)

Now I have downloaded the source code so that can maybe ask the question in a more detailed way.

I believe Zu and Xu are calculated this way

    pertOutput.Cl *= -q * area / (mass * u0);
    pertOutput.Cd *= -q * area / (mass * u0);

and that Zq and Xq are calculated this way

    pertOutput.Cl *= q * area * MAC / (2 * u0 * mass);
    pertOutput.Cd *= q * area * MAC / (2 * u0 * mass);

Is it a conscious decision that the first uses "-q" whereas the last uses "q" without the reversed sign ?

Best regards, Rodhern

[@Rodhern](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/144074-rodhern/)tech questions about <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr>-the-mod should be asked in the main <abbr title="Ferram Aerospace Research (mod)">FAR</abbr> thread; this one is for questions about craft design.

I have an aircraft that I'm working on that could use a bit of help from experienced plane builders. Spoilers ahead for KSA followers!

Spoiler

So I'm starting my plane building simple with a Cessna 180-type prop aircraft. It's experiencing some yaw or roll issues on the ground during takeoff and I want to find out if it's just the crappy 1.1.3 wheels or something actually wrong with the design. I'm currently doing my due diligence and working through videos, starting with [@Wanderfound](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/112611-wanderfound/)'s KerboDyne Flight Engineering, then moving on to some others (wasn't [@tetryds](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/50204-tetryds/).working on some?). But in the meantime figured I'd seek some help here.

Here is the problem in action (all wheels are locked, also tried with the normal trike gear and it was worse, but I hear those gear are really bad in 1.1.3):

<iframe allowfullscreen="true" frameborder="0" height="344" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/R8yJWXuKy7I?feature=oembed" width="459"></iframe>

And here is the Data+Stability Derivatives window for the speed range where things start to get all wobbly:

[![p2mOIQ7m.png](http://i.imgur.com/p2mOIQ7m.png)](http://i.imgur.com/p2mOIQ7.png)[![OPQAFFjm.png](http://i.imgur.com/OPQAFFjm.png)](http://i.imgur.com/OPQAFFj.png)[![lK6NQ61m.png](http://i.imgur.com/lK6NQ61m.png)](http://i.imgur.com/lK6NQ61.png)[![hKHOkWqm.png](http://i.imgur.com/hKHOkWqm.png)](http://i.imgur.com/hKHOkWq.png)[![lKfu4Ycm.png](http://i.imgur.com/lKfu4Ycm.png)](http://i.imgur.com/lKfu4Yc.png)

everything goes green at Mach 0.16 - 53.7 m/s. Craft was positioned on the floor of the <abbr title="SpacePlane Hangar">SPH</abbr> in the tail-drag position that it would be while on the ground normally.

I'm wondering if maybe it's the weight of the aircraft that could be having an effect from the red pitch values? I didn't touch the wing mass tweakable since I wanted them to be heavy before they learn how to make lighter wings

This plane is intentionally built just barely functional since it is the KSA kerbal's first fixed-wing aircraft in over 200 years after only basic glider flights and maybe a handful of Wright-brothers-esque powered flights were performed way back when. So this isn't meant to be perfect. But it should at least leave the ground! ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif ":P")

**Edited <time datetime="2016-10-05T16:25:50Z" title="10/05/2016 04:25  PM" data-short="7 yr">October 5, 2016</time> by Drew Kerman**

> 
> 
> 1 hour ago, Drew Kerman said:
> 
> 
> I have an aircraft that I'm working on that could use a bit of help from experienced plane builders. Spoilers ahead for KSA followers!
> 

Maybe you could improve the lift-to-weight somehow. Adding more wing or reducing the mass. At the moment I guess the plane is a bit strained that it must roll quite fast to take off.

**Edited <time datetime="2016-10-05T16:16:51Z" title="10/05/2016 04:16  PM" data-short="7 yr">October 5, 2016</time> by Rodhern**
  
my answer hid inside the quote

I'm 95% sure it's because your wheels are angled - just fix them upright & you'll probably find some other issue. The fixed gear is just terrible regardless.

[![29716040046_2d0c0cc542_b.jpg](https://c7.staticflickr.com/9/8463/29716040046_2d0c0cc542_b.jpg)](https://flic.kr/p/MgUtq3)

I had some issues with light aircraft & the small gear used as nosegear - it'd usually bounce hard & whack the tail into the ground, so I ended up installing tweakscale & using a scaled-down medium gear. TBH I'd have thought that would have been just as bad but it does seem to work better.

I don't know if you use [hangar grid mod](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/132775-11-113-hangar-grid-zero-deviation-v030-2016-apr-20/); it is a great help for aligning stuff straight.

Edit: Ahh, sorry, never mind, just now saw that you are well aware of the mod.

> Maybe you could improve the lift-to-weight somehow. Adding more wing or reducing the mass. At the moment I guess the plane is a bit strained that it must roll quite fast to take off.

I didn't tweak the wing strength at all, so I could lower that a lot to save mass. I don't want to though if I don't have to. It's their first time making aircraft parts. They should be heavy. Will give it a try tho

>

> using a scaled-down medium gear. TBH I'd have thought that would have been just as bad but it does seem to work better.

I scaled the nose gear and it went whacko so I didn't bother trying to scale any of the other wheels. Will give it a go, thx

But we can all agree it shouldn't be an aerodynamics issue?

> Rather like this one! Kind of reminds me of the British Vulcans, only nicer ![:wink:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif ";)")

Hey now, I've experienced attempted hearing loss by Vulcan several times! those things were amazing and very alien to see.

> 
> 
> 7 minutes ago, Drew Kerman said:
> 
> 
> But we can all agree it shouldn't be an aerodynamics issue?
> 

Yes - most of your derivative panels show the wing stalled, the one which isn't stalled shows some possible lateral stability issues but I'm not sure you're even getting up to that speed.
